en:e102.name: Tartrazine (E102)
en:e102.risk: May cause hyperactivity in children, allergic reactions

en:e110.name: Sunset Yellow FCF (E110)
en:e110.risk: May cause hyperactivity in children, allergic reactions

en:e122.name: Azorubine (E122)
en:e122.risk: May cause hyperactivity in children, allergic reactions

en:e124.name: Ponceau 4R (E124)
en:e124.risk: May cause hyperactivity in children, allergic reactions

en:e129.name: Allura Red AC (E129)
en:e129.risk: May cause hyperactivity in children, allergic reactions

en:e133.name: Brilliant Blue FCF (E133)
en:e133.status: Banned in Belgium, France, Germany, Switzerland, Sweden, Austria, Norway

en:e211.name: Sodium Benzoate
en:e211.known risks: May cause hyperactivity in children when combined with certain colors

en:e220.name: Sulphur Dioxide (E220)
en:e220.risk: Can cause asthma attacks, allergic reactions
en:e220.status: Banned on fresh meat and fish in some countries

en:e621.name: Monosodium Glutamate (MSG)
en:e621.known risks: Safe for general population, but some may experience headaches or nausea

en:e951.name: Aspartame (E951)
en:e951.risk: May cause headaches, mood changes in sensitive individuals

en:e320.name: Butylated Hydroxyanisole (BHA) (E320)
en:e320.status: Banned in Japan and parts of EU

en:e319.name: Tertiary-Butylhydroquinone (TBHQ) (E319)
en:e319.risk: May cause nausea, vomiting, ringing in the ears

en:e104.name: Quinoline Yellow (E104)
en:e104.risk: May cause hyperactivity in children, allergic reactions
en:e104.status: Banned in USA, Australia, Canada, EU

en:e151.name: Brilliant Black BN (E151)
en:e151.status: Banned in Denmark, Belgium, France, Germany, Switzerland, Sweden, Austria, Norway, USA

en:e123.name: Amaranth (E123)
en:e123.risk: Suspected carcinogen (linked to cancer in animals)

en:e127.name: Erythrosine (E127)
en:e127.risk: May cause thyroid tumors and endocrine disruption

en:e210.name: Benzoic Acid (E210)
en:e210.risk: May cause allergic reactions, exacerbates asthma and hyperactivity

en:e213.name: Calcium Benzoate (E213)
en:e213.risk: May cause allergic reactions in sensitive individuals

en:e250.name: Sodium Nitrite (E250)
en:e250.risk: Can form carcinogenic nitrosamines, risk of cancer
en:e250.status: Restricted in baby foods and cured meats

en:e251.name: Sodium Nitrate (E251)
en:e251.risk: Similar risks as sodium nitrite (nitrosamines formation)
en:e251.status: Restricted in baby foods and cured meats

en:e952.name: Cyclamate (E952)
en:e952.risk: Suspected carcinogen (bladder tumors in animal studies)
en:e952.status: Banned in USA and some other countries

en:e954.name: Saccharin (E954)
en:e954.risk: Linked to bladder cancer in rats (historically controversial)
en:e954.status: Previously banned (USA), now approved with caution

en:e924.name: Potassium Bromate (E924)
en:e924.risk: Possible carcinogen (kidney tumors in animal studies)
en:e924.status: Banned in EU, China, and many others (not in USA)

en:e927a.name: Azodicarbonamide (E927a)
en:e927a.risk: Linked to asthma in workers and potential breakdown into semicarbazide (possible carcinogen)

en:e443.name: Brominated Vegetable Oil (E443)
en:e443.risk: Contains bromine, may affect thyroid/endocrine system
en:e443.status: Banned in EU, Japan, and others

en:e284.name: Boric Acid (E284)
en:e284.risk: Toxic if ingested (reproductive and developmental toxin)
en:e284.status: Banned as a food additive in many countries

en:e285.name: Borax (Sodium Tetraborate) (E285)
en:e285.risk: Toxicity similar to boric acid (reproductive toxin)
en:e285.status: Banned as a food additive in EU and USA

en:e153.name: Vegetable Carbon (E153)
en:e153.status: Banned as a food additive in USA

en:e407.name: Carrageenan (E407)
en:e407.risk: May cause inflammation and gastrointestinal issues

en:e120.name: Cochineal (Carminic acid)
en:e120.known risks: May cause allergic reactions in sensitive individuals
